huntYears.SEASON_DATE_TEXT: Archery: Aug 19 - Sept 15, 2023  Muzzleloader: Sept 27 - Oct 5, 2023  Any Legal Weapon: Oct 21 - Oct 29, 2023

huntBios.GENERAL_INFORMATION:
Most hunters are able to locate 20-40 bucks a day. The Book Cliffs has one of the highest success rates for archery hunters in the state. Some hunters are disappointed in the quality of bucks so I would suggest trying to spend some time in the area to become familiar with the steep terrain and the quality of bucks. There are not many 30 in bucks on this unit. The average buck harvested on this unit is basically a 22” 4 point or 3x4. This area provides challenging terrain in a remote part of the state. There are other hunts that coincide with the muzzleloader deer hunt. They are: limited entry elk, limited entry bear, bear pursuit, and upland game hunts. In the past, deer hunters have had negative experiences with bear hunters in the area. Please be aware that everyone has an equal right to hunt this area. The Book Cliffs is an incredibly large area, but during summer and early fall most of the animals are congregated in a small area. If you really want to get away from ATV and vehicle traffic I would plan on hunting in the Little Creek WMA (roadless area).
The Ute Tribe as agreed to allow sportsmen to access this area across Ute Tribal trust lands. Once you leave the Sego Trailhead parking area and start down the Went Ridge trail you are on Tribal land for the first few miles. There are signs indicating that you have permission from the Tribe to use this route. We ask that you please keep this area clean and stay on the main trail until you are off of Ute Tribal land. This is a privilege and abuse of this area could lead to sportsmen losing this access permit. This hunt excludes all Ute Tribal lands.
huntBios.SAFETY_CONS:
This is a very remote location with some areas with limited access.  Cellular phone coverage is very spotty on this hunt unit.  Digital cell phones may show several bars but cannot always connect due to the distance to the cell towers.  Satellite phones do work in the area.  The biologist suggests hand held radios and even a "Spot Tracker" type of satellite messaging device for safety.  Make sure someone knows where you plan to camp and when you will return.

The Book Cliffs mountain range is one of the more remote areas in Utah.  There are no service stations for many miles.  Plan on bringing plenty of water, fuel, good tires with extra spares, and plenty of ice.

The Book Cliffs has a high bear population. Keep a clean camp and put your garbage in a place that is inaccessible to bears.  If you do have problems with bears please report them to the DWR Northeastern Regional Office as soon as possible (435 781-9453), or call the local dispatch center (435 789-4222).
huntBios.WEATHER_CONS: The weather on this hunt unit can vary dramatically during the hunting season.  Be prepared for rain, lightning, and snow.  Storms can cause muddy road conditions and flash floods in this region.
huntBios.MANAGEMENT_OBJ: 100~9000~4250~25–35~28.5~~~~~~~~For more detailed information on population and objective data please see the Big Game Annual Report Page.
huntBios.BIOLOGIST_NOTES:
Location of harvest:  You will find the majority of the deer located along the Divide Road.  The Book Cliffs range divides the north from the south with a long ridge that runs east to west.  The Seep Ridge Rd becomes the Divide Rd and runs east to Colorado and West to Steer Ridge.  The Book Cliffs has limited summer range.  The majority of the deer are going to be located along the Divide Rd.  

The deer will be relatively close to water sources.  There are numerous springs in the heads of the steep canyons.  The local ranches keep small ponds and reservoirs full, but don’t rely on them to always be full of water.  

Some of the areas where hunters have harvested in the past are: Rat Hole Ridge and Canyon, Rail Road Canyon, Black Horse and Saddle Horse Ridge, PR Springs, Horse Point, Moon Ridge, Cherry Mesa, Rock Springs Mesa, Cedar Camp, Steer Ridge, and Little Creek Ridge.  

The elevation plans a key role in where you will find deer during this time of year.  I suggest if you are not seeing deer to change your elevation.  

Migration Patterns:  The mule deer migrate to the higher elevation in late spring.  The does fawn on the summer range, and most of the bucks stay on the summer range until they strip their velvet.  The Book Cliffs has limited by summer range.  By mid-October the deer start to migrate to their winter range and can be found in the transitional zone.  This is a large area where the deer can hole up until storms start to move them to their winter range.  This area is made up of a lot of pinyon/juniper trees, mahogany, bitter brush, sage brush and grasses.    

From past biological studies we have found that approximately two thirds of the deer migrate to the north.

Scouting Tips:  A good spotting scope and binoculars are essential.  Scouting is most effective the last couple weeks before the hunt opens when they are more likely to stay in the same general area.  I would scout the higher ridges where oak brush is prominent.  Your preseason scouting can really pay off on this hunt.  The deer won’t start to leave the high country until mid-October.  The bucks might not be on the same ridge, but I would expect them to stay with-in a five mile radius.  In the hot early fall temperatures I would expect to see the most animals at prime time (1/2 hour before dawn and an hour before sunset.  There are several recovering burned areas along the Divide.  The oak brush is starting to get more established and creates great habitat for mule deer.     

Behavior:  Like other wildlife, they are most active in the early mornings and evenings.  Their behavior is dictated by the weather as well.  Rain provides more areas for them to drink, and can eliminate a need to travel more sustainable water sources.  The bucks will still be in bachelor groups of three to as many as ten in a group.  They will often bed down together so it can be difficult to close the distance.  They will tend to use the same game trails and with good pre scouting you might be able to pattern a bucks movements.  I would expect their behavior to change after all of the hunting pressure from opening weekend.

huntMaster.SPECIAL_PROVISIONS: Permit holders may hunt all limited-entry seasons. You must use the appropriate weapon during the appropriate season.
huntMaster.NOTES:
Baiting big game for the purposes of hunting is now illegal in Utah.
Click here for more information.

The use of all trail cameras (including both non-handheld transmitting and non-transmitting devices) in the harvest or to aid in the harvest of big game is prohibited between July 31 and Dec. 31. Click here for more information.
huntMaster.HARVEST_REPORTING: REQUIRED: click here or call 1-800-221-0659 to report your harvest. You must report your harvest, even if you did not take an animal, within 30 days of the season end date that is printed on your permit; failure to do so may result in you not being able to apply for big game species in subsequent years. Submitting teeth or other biological samples from your animal, or having your animal checked by a DWR representative or CWMU operator does NOT fulfill your mandatory harvest reporting requirement.

huntBoundaryInfos.LAND_OWNERSHIP:
The majority of land is managed by the BLM. There is a significant amount of SITLA land. There are several DWR Wildlife Management Areas (WMA). These areas are managed for wildlife and you can hunt on all these areas. There is private land and some of it is accessible through the DWR’s Walk-in-Access Program
http://wildlife.utah.gov/walkinaccess/
huntBoundaryInfos.WMA_IN_UNIT: Meadow Creek, Two Waters, Bitter Creek, and Willow Creek.
huntBoundaryInfos.CAMPGRND_INFO: Please direct all questions regarding maps and camping regulations to the Vernal BLM Field Office (http://www.blm.gov/ut/st/en/fo/vernal.html) BLM: 14 day camping limit and you have to move 30 miles after 14 days. DWR WMA’S: UDWR WMAs are limited to 14 days at one location. On the Willow Creek WMA, camping is not allowed. In the parcels that can be accessed by county roads there is no camping allowed. Camping is only allowed in the parcels where the roads are closed, like Meadow Creek.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIM_ACCESS_PTS: The Seep Ridge road is the best way to access where the bison are located.  You can stay on this road until you come to the Book Cliffs Divide.  Once on the Divide road I would travel west to Winter Ridge and Rock Springs Mesa.  You can also access the Divide from I-70 using the Hay Canyon Road.
huntBoundaryInfos.SUGGESTED_MAPS: Suggested Maps: BLM: Vernal, West Water, and they have a general map that labels most of the main roads.  There are several county signs and BLM signs to help direct you.
huntBoundaryInfos.ATV_VEH_ACCESS:
All roads and ATV trails on this unit are managed by the BLM, SITLA, and DWR, and regulations are covered in their Travel Management Plans. Please direct all questions regarding which roads and trails ATVs can be operated on to the Vernal BLM Field Office and SITLA. The DWR WMA’s are restricted to ATV and vehicle travel on established roads and trails.
This unit includes the Book Cliffs Little Creek WMA (Roadless Area). There is no vehicle access in this area and you are limited to horse or foot travel.

Suggested Maps: BLM: Vernal, West Water, and they have a general map that labels most of the main roads. There are several county signs and BLM signs to help direct you.
The Book Cliffs offers a challenging landscape. There are large ridges with steep canyons dividing them. Most of the canyons and ridges have roads or ATV trails to provide access. There are plenty of areas to hike and get away from the main roads. The hunting pressure will drastically decrease after opening weekend.
There are two roads that allow you to drive across the majority of the Book Cliffs. The Kings Well Road starts at the Seep Ridge Road on the west side, and it can take you all the way to the Dragon Road on the east side. The Indian Ridge Road starts at the Seep Ridge Road and goes through the bottom of Sweetwater, the top of McCook Ridge, Bitter Creek and to Big Park. It is a great road to locate deer during this time of year.
huntBoundaryInfos.PRIV_TRIBE_LAND_ISSUES:
The boundary excludes all of the Tribal Trust Lands. There is a large area of Ute Tribal Trust land to the west of the hunt unit. Road access across the Tribal land is permitted using county roads. All ATVs are prohibited on Tribal Lands; they must be trailered on access roads across Tribal lands.
There are some private ranches that post their property. There are also privately owned lands that allow access through the DWR Walk-in-Access Program.
huntBoundaryInfos.BOUNDARY_DESCRIPTION: Grand and Uintah counties--Boundary begins at Exit 164 on I-70 near the town of Green River; east on I-70 to the Utah-Colorado state line; north on this state line to the White River; west along this river to the Green River; south along this river to Swasey's Boat Ramp and the Hastings Road; south on this road to SR-19; south and east on SR-19 to Exit 164 on 1-70 near the town of Green River. EXCLUDES ALL NATIVE AMERICAN TRUST LAND WITHIN THE BOUNDARY. USGS 1:100,000 Maps: Huntington, Seep Ridge, Westwater. Boundary questions? Call the Price office, 435-613-3700 or the Vernal office, 435-781-9453.
